cmCourseInfo.description: A brief introductory survey of psychology as both a biological and social science. Topics will include physiological, learning, perceptual, motivational, cognitive, developmental, personality, abnormal, and social psychology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online.  Learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.  Opportunities for synchronous activity with instructors and classmates (e.g., virtual office hours) will be made available, but will not be required.  All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: A brief introductory survey of psychology as both a biological and social science. Topics will include physiological, learning, perceptual, motivational, cognitive, developmental, personality, abnormal, and social psychology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online.  Learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.  Opportunities for synchronous activity with instructors and classmates (e.g., virtual office hours) will be made available, but will not be required.  All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Fundamentals of descriptive and inferential statistics, including population and sampling distributions, simple association, probability, estimation, and hypothesis testing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Statistics I

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This will be an online asynchronous course. Lectures will be available asynchronously for students to view at any time. Students will have the opportunity to ask questions and clarifications about class through the Quercus Discussion Board, email, or virtual office hours.

cmCourseInfo.description: Fundamentals of descriptive and inferential statistics, including population and sampling distributions, simple association, probability, estimation, and hypothesis testing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Statistics I

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

This will be an online asynchronous course. Lectures will be available asynchronously for students to view at any time. Students will have the opportunity to ask questions and clarifications about class through the Quercus Discussion Board, email, or virtual office hours.

cmCourseInfo.description: Fundamentals of statistical analysis of experimental and observational data including linear models, the analysis of variance, a priori contrasts, post-hoc tests, power analysis and effect size calculations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Statistics II

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings from live synchronous lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. All delivery (apart from assignment and quiz/assessment instructions) will take place during lecture and/or tutorial.  There will be an oral assessment at the end of the course which will require students to have a microphone and camera to participate. During lecture/tutorial/office hours, a microphone will also be useful to engage in class activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: The developmental approach to the study of behaviour with reference to sensorimotor skills, cognition, socialization, personality, and emotional behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Development

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously.  Opportunities for online synchronous meetings and tutorials with professor and/or TAs will be made available at variable times throughout the semester.  For all such meetings, students will be able to either attend the online synchronous session or listen to a recording of the meeting asynchronously.  All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Contemporary areas of research in social psychology: social perception, attitudes, inter-personal relations, and group processes.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Social Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Course content will be delivered through a combination of pre-recorded lectures and linked live-streamed office hours/practical sessions during a set time each week. Students are expected to watch the lecture before the live online office hours. All live-streamed content will be recorded to allow for asynchronous viewing. All course assessments will be conducted online. Tests will be held on May 13th 11am-1pm;  May 27th 11am-1pm; and June 10th 11am-1pm.

cmCourseInfo.description: Theory and research in personality structure and dynamics: the interaction of cultural and biological factors in the development and expression of individual differences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Personality and Its Transformations

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be an online, asynchronous course. Lecture videos will be recorded and uploaded to the course website each week. Students will have the opportunity to attend synchronous office hours each week to ask questions and get feedback. There will also be opportunities for synchronous activities with your classmates. All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: A critical survey of concepts, theories, and the state of research in the area of psychopathology and therapeutic methods.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Abnormal Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. There will be opportunities for live discussion with the instructor and/or TA during weekly scheduled meetings that will be available through an online platform. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Quercus for submission of the assignments and tests. All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Concepts, theories, and applications of classical and contemporary learning theories, including classical and operant conditioning. Current theories of the physiological and anatomical basis of learning and memory, including synaptic plasticity, the role of the hippocampus, amygdala, frontal cortex and other brain regions. Theories will be related to a practical understanding and applications such as drug addiction, phobias and other disorders.
cmCourseInfo.title: Learning and Plasticity
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/COG250Y1, OR registered in the Cognitive Science program

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lecture recordings will be available online for students to view asynchronously. Opportunities for synchronous activities (e.g. virtual office hours) will be available but optional or an asynchronous option will also be made available. Students will be able complete the course entirely asynchronously without it adversely impacting their mark.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to research and theory on the neural and cognitive architecture of attention, memory, language, thinking and reasoning.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/COG250Y1, OR registered in the Cognitive Science program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will be available for students to view asynchronously. Synchronous office hours and review sessions will be scheduled throughout the term. It is recommended that students have a computer, a microphone, and internet access in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the physiological and psychological basis of perception across the different sensory modalities in humans and lower animals, with an emphasis on vision. Exploring visual perception such as shape and objects, scenes, colour, space, and motion as well as auditory perception of simple and complex sounds, and location. Further topics may include touch, including perception of temperature, pain and body posture, the chemical senses, and cross-modal influences of the senses on one another. In-class demonstrations may supplement the lectures.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sensation and Perception
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/COG250Y1, OR registered in the Cognitive Science program

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be given as a series of short videos totaling approximately 4-5 hours/week and optional synchronous meetings for 1-2 hours/week. The schedule of the synchronous meetings will be arranged during the first week of class, with the aim to accommodate as many students as possible. Students should watch the lecture videos before the synchronous meetings. The synchronous meetings will be recorded for asynchronous viewing. It is recommended that students have access to a computer with a microphone and camera.

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides students with a solid background into the biological basis of behaviour. Animal and human research topics include functional neuroanatomy, neural signalling, sensory and motor control, motivational systems, and hormones, and emotions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Physiological Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/COG250Y1, OR registered in the Cognitive Science program

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online.  Learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.  Opportunities for synchronous activity with instructors and classmates (e.g., virtual office hours) will be made available, but will not be required.  All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/focus/course/rop

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: March 26, 2021: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: A lecture course providing in-depth examination of specific topics/themes relating to Psychology. Content in any given year depends on instructor. Priority is given to PSY Major program students during the first enrolment period.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1, PSY201H1 (or exclusion), and one further 200-level PSY half-course

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online asynchronously, though live synchronous class discussions and/or office hours will be available each week at a specific time and day.  Participation in synchronous activities will be optional and asynchronous options will also be made available. All course assessments will be conducted online. Students will be able to complete the course entirely asynchronously without it adversely impacting their mark.

cmCourseInfo.description: Age changes in sensory and perceptual processes, motor skill, learning, memory, and personality. Theory, methodological problems, social, cultural, and environmental influences that shape behaviour and attitudes towards and among the elderly.
cmCourseInfo.title: Psychology of Aging

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be given as a series of short videos totaling approximately 4-5 hours/week. Students are expected to collaborate with a small group of students to discuss important questions related to real-life applications of course material. This collaboration can be done asynchronously or synchronously according to students' preferences. Students will have the option of attending a synchronous feedback conference about their written assignments with the instructor or TA. It is recommended that students have access to a computer with a microphone and camera to participate.

cmCourseInfo.description: Intensive study of social attitude development, description, measurement, modification, and organization.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology: Attitudes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Course content will be delivered through a combination of pre-recorded lectures and linked live-streamed office hours/practical sessions during a set time each week. Students are expected to watch the lecture before the live online office hours. All live-streamed content will be recorded to allow for asynchronous viewing. All course assessments will be conducted online.  The midterm test will be written on July 20th from 11am-1pm.

cmCourseInfo.description: One of the hallmarks of human behaviour is its diversity. Some of the ways in which we differ are thought to be relatively idiosyncratic (e.g., specific aspects of personality), whereas others are fairly systematic. Cultural psychology is one area of research in human behaviour that examines systematic differences resulting from individuals’ cultural backgrounds. This course will introduce you to the consideration of cultural variation in the study of human thought and behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cross-Cultural Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be an online, asynchronous course. Lecture videos will be recorded and uploaded to the course website each week. Students will have the opportunity to attend synchronous office hours each week to ask questions and get feedback. There will also be opportunities for synchronous activities with your classmates. All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deals with psychological issues in the law, with particular reference to criminal law. It focuses mainly on research that has been done on pretrial publicity, eyewitness testimony, rules of evidence, and other factors that might affect jury decisions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Psychology and the Law

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Course content will be delivered through a combination of pre-recorded lectures and linked live-streamed office hours/practical sessions during a set time each week. Students are expected to watch the lecture before the live online office hours. All live-streamed content will be recorded to allow for asynchronous viewing. All course assessments will be conducted online.  The midterm test will be written on July 20th from 4-6pm.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: March 3, 2021: Course added.

cmCourseInfo.description: Illustrates major methodologies within social psychology, such as attitude measurement, observation of small groups, and experiments. Course capacity is limited to 15 students and priority is given to PSY Specialists and Research Specialists during the first enrolment period.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology Laboratory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Course content will be delivered through a combination of pre-recorded (asynchronous) and live (synchronous) lectures. Students will be expected to watch asynchronous content prior to class meetings. Synchronous meetings will be delivered online (and recorded for later viewing or review). Students must have access to a computer that runs Windows, MacOS, or Linux, as a smartphone or tablet will not be sufficient for the data analysis component of the course. All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth review of the role of emotion in human psychology, with an emphasis on the links between emotion and cognition. Topics include theories of emotion, emotion regulation, emotional expression, and emotional experience, the role of emotion in decision-making, and the relationships between emotion, motivation and behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology of Emotion

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be accessible online for students to view asynchronously.  Opportunities for live review with instructors and classmates will take place during the period of 2-3pm Eastern on Tuesdays and Thursdays, and these will be recorded for asynchronous viewing.  A computer with a microphone and camera is recommended for students interested in participating in synchronous components of the course (not required). All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: A review of the field of positive psychology, which is the study of happiness and fulfillment. Topics include personal growth, meaning, hedonic and eudaimonic approaches to well-being, gratitude, awe, flow states, mindfulness and meditation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Positive Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online asynchronous course, however, course content will also be delivered as live-streamed lectures on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 12 – 3 pm EST.  All live-streamed content will also be recorded to allow for asynchronous viewing. Other opportunities for synchronous activity with instructors and classmates (e.g., discussions, virtual office hours) will be made available. A computer with a microphone and camera is recommended for students interested in participating in synchronous components of the course (not required). All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines various theories of how personality functioning may become impaired and corresponding psychotherapeutic interventions. Emphasis on empirical assessment of personality dysfunction and therapy effectiveness.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theories of Psychopathology and Psychotherapy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously.  Live virtual tutorial sessions (optional) will be offered at a few points throughout the semester.  Students will be able to participate in the discussion online (synchronously) or listen to a recording of the meeting (asynchronously).  All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Current theories and data on human memory: processes involved in encoding, storage, and retrieval.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human Memory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously. All course assessments will be conducted online.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Feb 17, 2020: Course added.

cmCourseInfo.description: The functional relevance of neurotransmitters, with particular emphasis on their role in mediating behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurochemical Basis of Behaviour

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

All lectures and assessments will be available online. Recordings of synchronous sections will be available for students to view asynchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: Daily, monthly, annual and other rhythms and methods of measuring them. Behavioural and physiological aspects of biological clocks. The importance of rhythms in experimental design, in research on brain function, in affective disorders, and the use animals make of rhythms in migration and other behaviours.
cmCourseInfo.title: Biological Rhythms

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be live-streamed to allow for synchronous (real time) online viewing. Lectures also will be recorded (possibly audio only) to allow for asynchronous viewing or review. All course assessments will be conducted online. Tests will be held during the regular class time according to the syllabus and will be followed by a lecture.

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/focus/course/rop

cmCourseInfo.description: An intensive laboratory or applied research project under the supervision of a Department of Psychology faculty member. Project must be academically demanding and uniquely suitable for the individual student. Additional information and applications are available at the department and on its website. This course is open to all Psychology program students.
cmCourseInfo.title: Individual Projects
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY202H1 (or exclusion), and appropriate background for the proposed work

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For PSY405H1 and 406H1, 'E' indicator: Students must first obtain consent of an instructor in the Department to supervise their project.  Information and proposal form is available on our website.  The proposal signed by student and supervisor should be submitted to the Undergraduate Administrator for approval via email (psy.undergrad@utoronto.ca).

Delivery Instructions

Proposed research projects must be able to be completed remotely, should on-campus activities not be possible or public health guidelines dictate otherwise.  Contact hours will be determined by project supervisor.

cmCourseInfo.description: An intensive laboratory or applied research project under the supervision of a Department of Psychology faculty member. Project must be academically demanding and uniquely suitable for the individual student. Additional information and applications are available at the department and on its website. This course is open to all Psychology program students.
cmCourseInfo.title: Individual Projects
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY202H1 (or exclusion), and appropriate background for the proposed work

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For PSY405H1 and 406H1, 'E' indicator: Students must first obtain consent of an instructor in the Department to supervise their project.  Information and proposal form is available on our website.  The proposal signed by student and supervisor should be submitted to the Undergraduate Administrator for approval via email (psy.undergrad@utoronto.ca).

Delivery Instructions

Proposed research projects must be able to be completed remotely, should on-campus activities not be possible or public health guidelines dictate otherwise.  Contact hours will be determined by project supervisor.

cmCourseInfo.description: This lecture course focuses on the social psychology of interpersonal relationships between individuals, especially romantic or close relationships and friendships. It surveys what social psychologists have learned about the development, maintenance, disruption or dissolution of personal relationships, as well as current social psychological theories of interpersonal relationships.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology of Interpersonal Relationships

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Class meetings will be held online synchronously, with recordings uploaded to Quercus asynchronously for those who cannot attend the class live.

cmCourseInfo.description: This lecture course focuses on the social psychology of interpersonal relationships between individuals, especially romantic or close relationships and friendships. It surveys what social psychologists have learned about the development, maintenance, disruption or dissolution of personal relationships, as well as current social psychological theories of interpersonal relationships.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology of Interpersonal Relationships

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

TBA

cmCourseInfo.description: This is a capstone lecture course surveying research on how the mind arises from the brain. The first objective of the course is to understand how processes in human brains (ranging from the firing of a single neuron to the dynamics of billions) support cognitive abilities (such as recognizing a face, remembering a birthday from childhood, understanding the words in a spoken lecture, or planning a route home from class). The second objective of the course is to understand the methods of contemporary cognitive neuroscience research, to enable students to read primary literature and to understand ongoing debates.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cognitive Neuroscience

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. There will be opportunities for live discussion with the instructor and/or TA during weekly scheduled meetings that will be available through an online platform. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Quercus for submission of the assignments and tests. All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: This lecture course discusses the role of brain and body in the expression and experience of emotion in humans considered through the experimental, physiological, theoretical, and clinical literatures.
cmCourseInfo.title: Physiology and Psychology of Emotion

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

All course delivery will be completely online, lectures will be asynchronous recordings that can be downloaded. Discussion boards will be asynchronous and all assessments will be online. A reliable internet connection is recommended for the course.
